quoteFirst: If he wants to wait I'll see him after the conference. Although"--Mr. Fernald glanced at the clock--"it's only
quoteLast: and he'd better get back to his room. Tell him I'll see him at the Cottage at nine, Mr. Brooke. As I was saying," and Mr. Fernald faced the company again, "I think it would be well to arrange for a longer course this Winter.
title: Left Guard Gilbert
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Caswell, Edward C., 1879-1963 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: _ The two reliefs which take place between 4 and 8 o'clock P.M., each of which continues only two hours, the intention being to change the turn of the night-watch every twenty-four hours.--_First watch._ From 8 P.M. till midnight.--_Middle-watch._ From midnight till 4 A.M.--_Morning-watch._ From
quoteLast: --_Watch_ is also a word used in throwing the deep-sea lead, when each man, on letting go the last turn of line in his hand, calls to the next abaft him, "Watch, there, watch!" A buoy is said to _watch_ when it floats on the surface of the water.

quoteFirst: They are to shift the watches each night, so that the same watch need not be on deck at the same hours. In order to effect this, the watch from
quoteLast: is divided into two half, or dog-watches, one from four to six; and the other from six to eight. By this means they divide the twenty-four hours into seven watches instead of six, and thus shift the hours every night.
title: Sea Stories
author: Brady, Cyrus Townsend, 1861-1920 [Editor]

quoteFirst: I asked whether _Alton Locke_ had been written in that room. "Yes," he said--"from
quoteTime: four to eight in the morning
quoteLast: s; and a young man was staying with me at the time with whom every day I used to ride, or perhaps hunt, when my task of writing was done."
title: Lippincott's Magazine of Popular Literature and Science, Volume 17, No. 099, March, 1876

quoteFirst: The man is a marvel—sixty-nine years old, a life of hardship, and as sturdy as a lion. Yet of the past night alone his hours had been: four to six in the afternoon on deck; eight to twelve on deck; and
quoteTime: four to eight in the morning
quoteLast: on deck. In a few minutes he would be relieved, but at midday he would again be on deck.
title: The Mutiny of the Elsinore
author: London, Jack, 1876-1916

quoteFirst: On one of those same lakes over which, on Saturday evening, sailors in embryo float their mimic craft--and one young gentleman, slightly in advance of the rest, directs a very miniature steamship--we see boards suggesting that daily, from
quoteLast: , the Orientals may immerse themselves in the limpid and most tempting waters. The depth, they are paternally informed, increases towards the centre, buoys marking where it is six feet; so that our Eastern friends have no excuse for suicide by drowning.
title: Mystic London; or, Phases of occult life in the metropolis
author: Davies, Charles Maurice, 1828-1910

title: Memoirs and Correspondence of Admiral Lord de Saumarez, Vol. I

quoteFirst: The whole fleet" failed to get into action. Why? Because the signal for a general chase was delayed from
quoteLast: , pending certain drill-ground manoeuvres, upon whose results, however well intended, no dependence could be placed in Mediterranean weather. During these four hours the wind was fresh,--the heel of a short summer's gale, invaluable to both sides,--and the enemy were using it to close the shore, where wind, the sole dependence for motive power, baffles most.
title:
The Life of Nelson, Volume 1
The Embodiment of the Sea Power of Great Britain
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914
